result.markdown:
--- title: Tibial Nerve --- Note the [tibial nerve]({{< var ref-tibial-nerve.path >}}) as it follows a distal path through the center of the tibiofemoral joint line, but then quickly courses medially towards the *tarsal tunnel* @jonesProjectFoundations2025. The [tibial nerve]({{< var ref-tibial-nerve.path >}}) enters the lower leg then pierces the soleus muscle @jonesProjectFoundations2025. # Roots # Pathway # Branches - Medial plantar - Lateral plantar - Sural (shared common fib and tibial) # Motor innervation - Triceps surae @gilroyAtlasAnatomy2020 - Gastrocnemius @gilroyAtlasAnatomy2020 - Soleus @gilroyAtlasAnatomy2020 - Plantaris @gilroyAtlasAnatomy2020 - Popliteus @gilroyAtlasAnatomy2020 - Tibialis posterior @gilroyAtlasAnatomy2020 - Flexor digitorum longus @gilroyAtlasAnatomy2020 - Flexor hallucis longus @gilroyAtlasAnatomy2020 ::: {#tbl-oian .cell message='false' execution_count=1} ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-display} ```{=html}

Innervations {.striped .hover} # Cutaneous Innervation - Medial sural cutaneous n. @gilroyAtlasAnatomy2020 - Medial and lateral calcaneal brs. @gilroyAtlasAnatomy2020 - Lateral dorsal cutaneous n. @gilroyAtlasAnatomy2020 # Plantar reflex {#plantar-reflex} The *tibial n.* serves as the afferent aspect in the plantar reflex loop. Plantar reflex is a superficial reflex where stroking of the lateral sole of the calcaneus to the base of 5th metatarsal results in toe plantarflexion. An **abnormal** plantar reflex refers to when you stroke the foot and the 1st toe dorsiflexes while toes 2-5 abduct. This abnormal plantar reflex is known as a positive "Babinski sign" and is often observed in patients with corticospinal/UMN lesions. # Dysfunction Entrapment sites: - Indirect - - Direct - Soleus origin - Tarsal tunnel # Palpation - Patient positioned in prone - Palpate [lateral head of the gastrocnemius]({{< var ref-gastrocnemius.origin >}}) at the distal joint line of the [tibiofemoral joint]({{< var ref-tibiofemoral-joint.path >}}). - Move *medially* and you should be able to strum the tibial nerve as it runs vertically. - Follow the tibial nerve inferiorly to palpate where it passes through the [soleus origin]({{< var ref-soleus.origin >}}). - This can be a place where the tibial nerve can be entrapped @jonesProjectFoundations2025. # Treatment - [Soleus origin release]({{< var ref-soleus.release >}}) # Notes "The tibial nerve, the larger of the two branches of the sciatic nerve, begins its own course in the upper part of the popliteal space. It descends vertically through this space, passing between the heads of the gastrocnemius muscle to the posterior aspect of the leg, and to the posteromedial aspect of the ankle, where its terminal branches serve the foot and ankle (see Chapter 21)." @duttonDuttonOrthopaedicExamination2020 "The tibial nerve supplies the gastrocnemius, plantaris, soleus, popliteus, tibialis posterior, flexor digitorum longus, and flexor hallucis longus muscles. Articular branches pass to the knee and ankle joints." @duttonDuttonOrthopaedicExamination2020 # Entrapment {#entrapment} ::: {.callout title="Reading list"} - Tibkal nerve p373 @DynamicNeurologicalStabilizationClinicalRehabilitation2014 :::
